greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the fixed point reached by the sum of divisors of n without multiplicity (with the convention a(1)=0).
comment: For n>1, the sequence reaches a fixed point, which is prime.
a(n) = n if n is prime.
a(n) = n/2 + 2 if n is in A108605.
a(n) = n/4 + 2 if n is in 4*A001359. (End)
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: Starting with 60 = 2^2 * 3 * 5 as the first term, add the prime factors of 60 to get the second term = 2 + 3 + 5 = 10. Then add the prime factors of 10 = 2 * 5 to get the third term = 2 + 5 = 7, which is prime. (Successive terms of the sequence will be equal to 7.) Hence a(60) = 7.
mathematica: f[n_] := Module[{a}, a = n; While[ !PrimeQ[a], a = Apply[Plus, Transpose[FactorInteger[a]][[1]]]]; a]; Table[f[i], {i, 2, 100}]
xref: A008472(n) is sum of prime divisors of n. Cf. A029908.
results.author: _Joseph L. Pe_, Oct 15 2002
